title: ISic000624. Fragments of consular fasti
body:
a
1[s͡u͡f(fecti) K(alendis) --- P(ublius) Alfen]u[s]
2[--- C(aius) Coc]ceiu[s]
3[App(ius) Claudius] C(aius) Norba[nus]
4[s͡u͡f(fecti) K(alendis) Iu]l(iis) L(ucius) Lentul[us]
5Sept(embribus) L(ucius) Philipp[us]
6[L(ucius) C]aninius M(arcus) Agrip[pa]
7K(alendis) Iul(iis) T(itus) Statil[ius]
8L(ucius) Gellius M(arcus) Cocce[ius]
9s͡u͡f(fecti) K(alendis) Iul(iis) Q(uintus) Mar[cius]
10SSept(embribus) L(ucius) Noniu[s]
11L(ucius) Cornifici(us) Sex(tus) Pom[peius]
12s͡u͡f(fecti) K(alendis) Iul(iis) P(ublius) Dolab[ella]
13Sept(embribus) T(itus) Peduc[aeus]
14L(ucius) Scriboni(us) L(ucius) Atratinus
15s͡u͡f(fecti) K(alendis) Iul(iis) Paul(us) Ae[milius]
16C(aius) Mem[mius]
17Sept(embribus) [M(arcus) Herennius]

1[bella civilia p(opuli) R(omani)]
2confe[cta]
3[I]mp(erator) Caes[ar V Sex(tus) Appuleius]
4K(alendis) Oc[t(obribus) Potitus Valeri(us)]
5[I]mp(erator) Cae[sar VI M(arcus) Agrippa]

a
1[......---.......]U[.]
2[---.....]CEIU[.]
3[............]CNORBA[...]
4[........]LLLENTUL[..]
5SEPTLPHILIPP[..]
6[...]ANINIUSMAGRIP[..]
7KIULTSTATIL[...]
8LGELLIUSMCOCCE[...]
9S͡U͡FKIULQMAR[....]
10SSEPTLNONIU[.]
11LCORNIFICISEXPOM[.....]
12S͡U͡FKIULPDOLAB[....]
13SEPTTPEDUC[....]
14LSCRIBONILATRATINUS
15S͡U͡FKIULPAULAE[......]
16CMEM[....]
17SEPT[...........]

1[................]
2CONFE[...]
3[.]MPCAES[................]
4KOC[...............]
5[.]MPCAE[..............]

Facsimile Images

Apparatus criticus

  • Provisional text after Manganaro and Salomies

translation

commentary

The preserved consular fasti cover the years 39-34 and 31-28 BCE. The material and lettering of the list makes it almost certain that these are part of the same monumental display of the calendar and local aedilician and duumviral fasti (for which see ISic000662), but it is not possible to connect them directly. Ruck argues that the calendar post-dates 8 BCE, but is probably Augustan; she also argues that the preserved consular fragments belong to a single column, with the lower fragment marking the end of a column. Consequently at least one more column must have existed, to carry the consuls down to at least 8 BCE. But whether these fasti stood on the same surface as the calendar or another part of the underlying monument is unknown.

bibliography

  • 1996.0788 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001283
  • 1991.0894, 1988.0625 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001283
  • Manganaro 1963 13-19 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001848
  • Manganaro 1964 38-40 tav.15 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001842
  • Bacci 1984-1985 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10002174
  • Salomies 1988 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001421
  • Manganaro 1988 43 tav.XIII.20b https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001427
  • Rüpke 1995 133-138) https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001616
  • Wilson 1995-1996 81 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001508
  • Ruck 1996 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001470
